image.altText: a close-up of an aboriginal man in army uniform looking at camera

props.synopsis: In an era of spy satellites and nuclear submarines, Australia's vast northern borders are still being defended by squadrons of soldiers using techniques that are thousands of years old.

title.children: From a secret location in the Top End, these soldiers use ancient techniques to defend Australia

image.altText: An image of Brittany Higgins next to an image of Bruce Lehrmann.

props.synopsis: Brittany Higgins's allegation she was raped by former Liberal staffer Bruce Lehrmann in then-minister Linda Reynolds's office has had far-reaching consequences, and perhaps the most extraordinary part of the tale has been playing out in Federal Court this week.

title.children: Bruce Lehrmann's defamation action was set to be a re-run of his trial, but some key evidence is unravelling

image.altText: a composite image one showing a flooded are with trees an looking green the other a sunset after a hot day

props.synopsis: Next week to bring a repeat of wild weather across many parts of Australia, after a surprisingly wet November.

title.children: East Coast Low makes way for severe thunderstorms, a December scorcher, and Coral Sea cyclone

image.altText: a woman holds a handful of discarded vapes from a bin wearing a high-vis vest

props.synopsis: Disposable vapes are causing a spike in fires at recycling plants with industry experts saying they're battling at least five fires a day in Queensland alone and an increasing riskÂ in other states due to lithium-ion batteries.

title.children: Illegally dumped vapes causing fires daily in Queensland recycling facilities due to exploding lithium-ion batteries

image.altText: A person wearing a keffiyeh holds their fingers up in a peace sign, a Palestinian flag is in the background.

props.synopsis: What happened in the aftermath of the Sydney Theatre Company performance is a reflection of how the latest conflict in the Middle East has erupted into bitter and dangerous reductionism in political debates in Australia, writes Laura Tingle.

title.children: Three young actors took to the stage in keffiyehs. A bitter and dangerous debate was unleashed

image.altText: people carry someone on a stretcher while stepping through debris

props.synopsis: After the collapse of the week-long truce, fighting has resumed with Israeli warplanes pounding Gaza while Hamas sent rockets from the enclave into nearby towns.Â

title.children: Israeli leaflet drop warns southern Gaza of coming conflict

image.altText: A woman with a trolley stands in a stocked supermarket aisle.

props.synopsis: The product feels lighter, or it's smaller, and you can't quite put your finger on the changeâ¦ but there is a change. Shrinkflation is becoming more widespread, but can anything be done about it, asks David Taylor.

title.children: 'Shrinkflation' is becoming more widespread, but there's one thing shoppers can do to avoid it

image.altText: A woman with black hair leans in to a man wearing a green jumper.

props.synopsis: The Kremlin is yet to comment on the alleged poisoning attempt on the wife of Ukraine's chief spy, but if Russian agents are involved, it suggests that Soviet era tactic remains alive and well in the new age of war.

title.children: Why female Putin critics from Russia and Ukraine might be the target of a new wave of poisonings

image.altText: George Santos waves. He is wearing distinct sunglasses with square-shaped lenses.

props.synopsis: Just before his fate was sealed by a history-making vote to expel him from congress, the New York Republican found himself at the centre of another shocking allegation.Â

title.children: George Santos expelled from US congress after fraud findings over botox and OnlyFans  â and one last shock claim

image.altText: COP primer - Oil derricks

props.synopsis: Talks about how to wean the world off fossil fuels are taking place in one of the globe's leading petrostates. Massive increases in green energy and who should pay will be up for discussion.

title.children: What is COP28? Here's what to expect at this year's UN climate talks

image.altText: A child leans on a scooter while his mother smiles down at him, inside a lift

props.synopsis: The number of no-kids zones in South Korea has exploded in the past decade, but some parents say it's creating a culture where children are unwelcome and restricted from learning how to behave in public.

title.children: South Korea is desperate for more babies â just not in cafes or restaurants, please

image.altText: Chris Dawson wearing suit and tie and glasses

props.synopsis: The woman, who cannot be identified for legal reasons, claims she was groomed and sexually abused by the former teacher at a public school on Sydney's northern beaches in the 1970s and 1980s.

title.children: Woman sexually abused by Chris Dawson as a schoolgirl settles lawsuit against New South Wales

image.altText: An illustration of a wall with rainbow flags and white paper.

props.synopsis: One year on from the "white paper protests", one of the biggest displays of civil disobedience in China since the 1989 Tiananmen massacre, young people are finding creative ways to express political dissent.

title.children: 'Resist against forgetting': Young Chinese people are finding creative ways to keep 'white paper' protest alive

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a suit and tie.

props.synopsis: Australia's experiment with 'marketisation' of employment services has failed, and we must refocus on helping unemployed people, a new parliamentary report says.

title.children: Why Australia's employment services network needs to stop prioritising profits over people

image.altText: Man in black shirt hugging his mum, lady in jeans with colourful top, packing up gear in front of grey tent and trailer

props.synopsis: Kristy and Matt Turner were forced to move earlier this year when the owners of the house they were renting moved back in. It happened at a time whenÂ dozens of state housing homes sat empty in their regional South Australian town.

title.children: Mother and son finally find somewhere to rent after 70 days living in a tent â but it's four hours from home

image.altText: A woman in a black suit and pink shirt with dark hair, is back to back with a man in a black suit and white shirt.

props.synopsis: Islamophobic and antisemitic incidents in Australia are at unprecedented levels as the Israel-Gaza war rages.Â

title.children: 'Hate attacks, death threats': Unprecedented rise in Islamophobia and anti-Semitism amid Israel-Gaza war

image.altText: Dave story

props.synopsis: The momentum of women's sport is in unstoppable motion, but the wages of some codes compared to others shows not all sports are created equal, writes David Mark.

title.children: Women's sport is rising faster than ever before â but which sports are keeping pace with wages?

image.altText: Cleveland Dodd's casket being carried to his grave.

props.synopsis: Hundreds of mourners gather for the funeral service for the teenager who died inside WA's juvenile detention system.

title.children: Casket holding Cleveland Dodd's body lowered into the ground on Yamaji country after boy's death in custody

image.altText: Former digger Keith Fowler with the street named after him.

props.synopsis: Mr Fowler was the last surviving member of his machine gun battalion and was one of more than 22,000 Australians taken prisoner by the Japanese.

title.children: World War II veteran Keith Fowler dies at 103

image.altText: A blue, purple, green and red coloured bird feeding two baby birds, perched in a tree.

props.synopsis: With its soft, twittering tune and brilliantly bright plumage, the scarlet-chested parrot is one of Australia's rarely sighted birds that is rejoicing in recent rain in South Australia's Riverland.

title.children: After the floods comes the feast, as rare birds relish heavy rain

image.altText: English singer-songwriter, Jessie Ware

props.synopsis: This week, singer Jessie Ware re-lit the disco fire in my soul enough to make me want to go out dancing. But where? There's no dance scene for women my age anymore â and maybe it's been ever thus, writes Virginia Trioli.

title.children: When you're on the 'wrong' side of club-ready, where do you go to dance?

image.altText: Pokemon characters on an advert

props.synopsis: A search for the operator of mysterious websites using unlicensed PokÃ©mon branding to spruik an upcoming game has proved trickier than catching the Nintendo characters themselves.

title.children: When PokÃ©mon tried to sue a company purportedly based in Western Sydney, it led to a global search for its operators

image.altText: Students in a classroom with male teacher in background.

props.synopsis: Australia's teachers are not equipped to deal with rising levels of disruption in classrooms, a Senate inquiry has found, while calling for students to be taught how to behave.

title.children: Teachers need better training to deal with increasingly disruptive school students, inquiry says

image.altText: Grey haired man wearing grey shirt putting on nasotracheal tube around nose and ears

props.synopsis: Giuliano Gaspri spent eight months in hospital with COVID. He's part of a study of long COVID patients which hasn't found the cause, but did find life can return to normal with time.Â

title.children: Long COVID research offers 'light at the end of the tunnel', finding symptoms ease over time

image.altText: Ben Dwarshuis is bowled

props.synopsis: India seals the T20 international series after putting Australia in a spin to win the fourth match fairly comfortably in Raipur.

title.children: New-look Australia loses fourth T20 against India

image.altText: A close up of Jim speaking in a suit and orange tie outside a building during the day.

props.synopsis: As Federal Treasurer Jim Chalmers completes the finishing touches on his mid-year economic outlook, heâs been urged by his state and territory counterparts to make the GST 'no-worse-off guarantee' a permanent arrangement.

title.children: Jim Chalmers urged by states and territories to make GST arrangements permanent

image.altText: A Spanish male tennis player pumps his left fist as he celebrates winning a point.

props.synopsis: Former tennis world number one Rafael Nadal will return at the Brisbane International warm up event for the Australian Open in January, the Spaniard said on Friday.

title.children: Rafael Nadal to make tour return at Brisbane International

image.altText: A side profile of a young boy with glasses with a long red mullet, which is blowing in the wind.

props.synopsis: Queenslander Jayce Bowers, 12, has already won a state title for his meticulously cultivated mane. This weekend he will see how his glorious 'do fares against the very best in the nation and beyond at Mulletfest.

title.children: 12-year-old Queenslander set to go mullet-to-mullet with world's best
